Description: Fragmentary cast headdress in copper alloy; representing a Hathoric crown, formed of sun disc and horns; fitting belonging to a figure of a goddess, maybe Hathor or more likely Isis; corroded; hole in surface of disc.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The Hathoric crown was first associated with the goddess Hathor but from the Late Period onwards, it was largely used for Isis (Hill and Schorsch 2007, 151, note 5). Isis is also a common topic among Naukratis bronzes. This crown in copper alloy could have topped a figure made from a different material. On Hathoric crowns see also: Weiss 2012, 868-870, Pl. 68a-c. Hill, M. and Schorsch D. (eds.), 2007, Gifts for the gods: images from Egyptian temples, Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten : Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MB.218) (phase 3)
